metadata.title: Top Coronavirus Research Topics using NLP: May 2020 | by Adrian H. Raudaschl | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Top Coronavirus Research Topics using NLP: May 2020
metadata.description: Back in March when I first tried to topic model all the SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pre-print articles submitted to SSRN, there were only 75 papers, and now just two months later that number has ballooned…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: The Abnormal ACE2 Expression Correlated with Immune Infiltration May Worsen Progression After SARS-CoV-2 Infection in UCEC and KIRP
Characteristics of Respiratory Virus Infection During the Outbreak of 2019 Novel Coronavirus in Beijing.
The Prediction for Development of COVID-19 in Global Major Epidemic Areas Through Empirical Trends in China by Utilising State Transition Matrix Model
Focusing on the Treatment of COVID-19: A Comprehensive Analysis of 226 Trials Registered on ClinicalTrials.gov and ChiCTR
The Impact of School Closure for COVID-19 on the US Healthcare Workforce and the Net Mortality Effects
Detection of 2019-nCov in Saliva and Characterization of Oral Symptoms in COVID-19 Patients
Mental Health Status of Survivors Following COVID-19 in Wuhan, China: A Descriptive Study
Clinical Features Predicting Mortality Risk in Older Patients with COVID-19

all_paragraphs: Back in March when I first tried to topic model all the SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pre-print articles submitted to SSRN, there were only 75 papers, and now just two months later that number has ballooned to 346. I’m super interested to see if there are any new patterns in the topics these papers are discussing.

Before I was literally going through each pre-print submission listed on the Elsevier Coronavirus centre webpage then copying and pasting the title and main findings into a spreadsheet to run through my Gensim LDA modelling script.

With the explosion in new academic papers, I just can’t keep up, and now I have a web scraper script paired with some REGEX to extract specific sections like the conclusion and findings to ingest all that juicy content.

I’ve seen Semantic Scholar has a cross-publisher COVID-19 academic database, but it doesn’t look great. Last I checked their index included strangely irrelevant content like bacterial pneumonia and antibiotic therapies. I’m also not sure if it contains pre-print material.
In any case, like last time I have taken the latest academic pre-print content, run it over an LDA topic model script and identified 75 topics for 346 papers with a coherence of 0.5602.
There is some pretty exciting stuff in here from predicting when quarantine could be lifted to the mental strain on healthcare workers caused by school closures, so let’s get started.
REMEMBER this post is by no means a scientific review, but rather a little experiment I wanted to share. Read pre-prints with caution as the claims made are unverified.
Topic Keywords: cell, cd, ace, kirp, expression, positively, ucec, immune, reduce, highlight
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 54%

ACE2 is a receptor for SARS-CoV-2 entry into cells. There is a lot of research into expression levels of ACE2 and severity of the disease. The most representative paper below looks specifically at the correlation of ACE2 with immune infiltration and progression in Uterine Corpus Endometrial Carcinoma (UCEC) & Kidney renal papillary cell carcinoma (KIRP) after SARS-CoV-2 infection.
Most Representative Paper: The Abnormal ACE2 Expression Correlated with Immune Infiltration May Worsen Progression After SARS-CoV-2 Infection in UCEC and KIRP
Topic Keywords: infection, virus, patient, high, group, flu, diagnose, count, wbc, rsv
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 38%

Other respiratory viruses also cause similar symptoms as COVID-19 does. This can make an initial diagnosis very challenging. The more presentative paper here summarises the composition of pathogens in fever clinic patients and analysed characteristics of different respiratory viruses infection.
Most Representative Paper: Characteristics of Respiratory Virus Infection During the Outbreak of 2019 Novel Coronavirus in Beijing.
Topic Keywords: rate, scenario, hubei, daily, number, mar, direct, approximately, south, korea
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 38%

There is lots of data mining happening to build models to predict the global trend of the epidemic, which will hopefully allow us to allocate international medical resources better and instruct the strategy for quarantine.
Most Representative Paper: The Prediction for Development of COVID-19 in Global Major Epidemic Areas Through Empirical Trends in China by Utilising State Transition Matrix Model
Topic Keywords: treatment, study, trial, chinese, phase, medicine, intervention, manifestation, preliminary, woman
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 36%

There are many clinical trials on the treatment of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19); however, there is a lack of systematic understanding of the clinical trials of COVID-19. The associated paper with this topic argues that the number of existing patients of COVID-19 is not enough to support the hundreds of clinical trials started. The design of multi-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials is lacking.
Most Representative Paper: Focusing on the Treatment of COVID-19: A Comprehensive Analysis of 226 Trials Registered on ClinicalTrials.gov and ChiCTR
Topic Keywords: healthcare, provide, care, household, parameter, school, medical, closure, lead, decline
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 33%

Healthcare workers with school-age children find themselves in a situation of choosing between work and staying at home with their kids. This problem is further exacerbated by the cost and access to childcare during the lockdown.
Most Representative Paper: The Impact of School Closure for COVID-19 on the US Healthcare Workforce and the Net Mortality Effects
Topic Keywords: study, high, stage, condition, saliva, patient, detection, demonstrate, critically_ill, viral
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 36%

An increasing number of studies are finding a positive saliva detection rate was as high as 75% (3/4) in critically-ill patients. Saliva may be a new source of diagnostic specimens for the critically-ill.
Most Representative Paper: Detection of 2019-nCov in Saliva and Characterization of Oral Symptoms in COVID-19 Patients
Topic Keywords: discharge, infection, associate, survivor, hospital, post, worry, family, range, recurrence
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 34%

There is an increasing concern about the mental health of patients who survive a COVID-19 infection and are concerned about residual respiratory symptoms. This representative paper found about 10 percent of COVID-19 survivors would develop anxiety or depression, because of post-discharge residual respiratory symptoms, worry about recurrence and infection to others.
Most Representative Paper: Mental Health Status of Survivors Following COVID-19 in Wuhan, China: A Descriptive Study
Topic Keywords: model, predict, indicator, score, early, predictive, regression, accurately, ratio, cohort
Percentage of Documents With Topic: 28%

Many papers are trying to predict which patients are most at risk of severe infection as to provide intervention earlier. This tends to involve analysis of clinical features. Still, some studies are showing no difference in major symptoms was observed between dying and discharged patients, whereas variations in vital signs and results of laboratory tests were observed.
Most Representative Paper: Clinical Features Predicting Mortality Risk in Older Patients with COVID-19

It was enjoyable pulling out the LDA and seeing how things have changed these last few months. Compared with the previous time I tried this, the number of topics is becoming far broader, but a few are really starting to stand out like the research around ACE2 receptors and prediction modelling for severity.
The further we are from the results of our decisions, the easier it is to keep our current views rather than update them. — The Great Mental Models
Full Disclaimer: I work as a product manager for Elsevier. This blog post and analysis is of own creation and in no way represent the thoughts and opinions of Elsevier.
GitHub Repo with python scripts input data and outputs:
If you enjoyed the article, be sure also to check out my last topic model article from February
